title: Specialized Tarmac SL8 vs. Tarmac SL7: Every difference compared

Specialized Tarmac SL8 vs. Tarmac SL7: Every difference compared

The Tarmac SL8 is Specialized’s replacement for the pro-level Tarmac SL7, with the brand boasting better aerodynamics, lighter weight, improved comfort and a lower headline price.

So what’s different between the two bikes? We’ve cut through the marketing to tell you exactly what’s changed with the new Tarmac SL8, as well as what is the same as the older Tarmac SL7.

Which bike is better? On paper it’s clearly the SL8 as you’d expect, but some of the differences are fairly subtle and if you already have an SL7 and are happy with it, the SL8 is unlikely to feel like a radical upgrade.

Specialized Tarmac SL8 vs. Tarmac SL7: Key features at a glance

Tarmac SL8

  • Frame weight 685g
  • 16.5 watts faster than the Tarmac SL7, faster than the Venge
  • One-piece Roval Rapide Cockpit
  • Identical geometry to the Tarmac SL7
  • 32mm tyre clearance – same as the SL7
  • 33 per cent greater stiffness-to-weight than the SL7
  • Five bike spec: prices from £6,000 to £12,000
  • Two frameset options: FACT 10r, £3,500 and FACT 12r, £4,750
  • Read our first ride Specialized Tarmac SL8 review

Tarmac SL7

  • Frame weight 800g
  • Slightly less aero than the Venge
  • Two-piece Roval Rapide bar and stem
  • Six bike specs: prices from £5,000 to £13,000
  • One frameset option: FACT 12r, £4,500
  • Read our full Specialized Tarmac SL7 review

Aerodynamics: it’s a nose thing

At the pointy end of the market occupied by the Tarmac aero is, as Specialized has said, everything. The headline-grabbing figure is the watts saved and Specialized claims a significant 16.6 watts on a flat 40km course when riding at 45kmh. 

That number makes the Tarmac SL8 faster even than the late lamented Venge aero bike to which everyone compares the Tarmac. The brand says this equates to 128 seconds over the parcours of the Milan-San Remo classic. 

Famously, Specialized said that the Tarmac SL7 was almost as aero as the Venge when it was launched and ceased selling the Venge as a consequence.

Specialized says that the Tarmac SL8’s watt savings are due to three factors: a deeper head tube, a slimmer seat tube and the new Roval Rapide integrated cockpit. The designers have left less aerodynamically important parts of the bike alone, concentrating on smoothing the airflow over the frame’s leading edge.

The new, extended nose to the head tube, which Specialized calls Speed Sniffer, is a consequence of the UCI loosening the rules on tube profiles between the genesis of the SL7 and the SL8. Specialized says that although this adds 25g to the frame weight, it has allowed it to adopt a more aero profile for the head tube’s leading edge rather than following the round shape of the steerer.

At the rear, the seat tube is thinner on the SL8 than on the SL7, which reduces its aero profile, but has identical lateral stiffness. It also adds to the SL8’s comfort figures, providing Specialized’s 6 per cent compliance increase figure from more fore/aft flex. 

It’s based on that of the non-aero Aethos, as Specialized says that there are minimal aero gains from a Kammtail shape, as the air flowing around the seat tube and seatpost is already turbulent. 

For Shimano builds, the Di2 battery is held in a cradle below the bottom of the seatpost, rather than being inserted into it, as it was on the Tarmac SL7, as the seatpost is now too narrow to house it.

Cockpit: subtle savings

The latest Roval Rapide cockpit, as fitted to the S-Works Tarmac SL8, was launched in June as a standalone item. It’s claimed to save 4 watts over the separate bar and stem of the Tarmac SL7, although it does reduce adjustability. The absence of a stem faceplate is a significant contributor to the savings.

But it’s offered in a total of 15 width/effective stem length combinations, chosen on the basis of Specialized’s Retul bike fit data. Unfortunately, you’ll get the cockpit that Specialized has chosen for you rather than being able to choose your preferred configuration.

Specialized claims weight savings from the one piece design over the Tarmac SL7’s cockpit – 50 grams of them – as well as increased stiffness. 

The Tarmac SL8 is also compatible with the SL7’s separate stem design if you want more adjustability and it can be used with any standard road bike handlebars. Pro spec bikes have a two-piece Roval Rapide carbon bar and Tarmac SL7 stem fitted, while Expert specs have Specialized Expert alloy bars with the Tarmac SL7 stem.

All figures except angles in mm

Geometry-wise, Specialized says that there’s no difference between the Tarmac SL8 and the SL7, with its Retul fit database allowing it to refine the fit across the whole range of seven bike sizes.

That’s not strictly accurate as the SL8 frame has a 10mm higher stack and a 3mm shorter reach. But once the different head tube top cap design is taken into account, the stack and reach to stem figures for the two bikes are exactly the same, so you should be able to achieve an identical fit.

There are slight differences in the head tube length: that on the SL8 is 6mm or 7mm longer, depending on frame size. The fork on the SL8 is 4mm longer across the board and the seat tube 2mm shorter, but neither figure affects the bottom bracket height and drop. The SL8 has clearance for 32mm tyres – same as the SL7. 

Specialized Tarmac SL8 vs. Tarmac SL7 weight

While the Tarmac SL7 weighed a claimed 800g, the new SL8 has a claimed weight of 685g for a painted size 56cm bike. That’s over 100g lighter than the Tarmac SL7 and sits full race-ready builds complete with pedals on the UCI 6.8kg weight limit.

In contrast, the S-Works Tarmac SL7 only hits the same weight without pedals or bottle cages. According to Specialized, the SL8 would be 16 seconds faster when climbing the Col du Tourmalet thanks to the weight reduction and 4 seconds faster on the way back down the other side due to the aero improvements.

As well as the frame, there are other weight reductions in everything from the seatpost via the fork through to the headset compression ring, in total shaving 249g off the bike’s claimed weight.

Stiffness-to-weight

Specialized says that the Tarmac SL8 is stiffer than the SL7 thanks to its revised carbon fibre layup. Along with the reduced weight of the Tarmac SL8 frame, Specialized says that this results in a stiffness-to-weight figure for the Tarmac SL8 that is 33 per cent higher than the Tarmac SL7.

Specialized also claims that ride compliance, which we judged a plus for the SL7 when we reviewed it, has increased by 6 per cent despite the same frame stiffness figures.

Specialized Tarmac SL8 vs. Tarmac SL7 price

The S-Works Tarmac SL7’s price reached scary numbers. These have been pegged back in the Tarmac SL8. A £1,000 price drop for the equivalent spec may sound like a lot, but in a bike priced at £12,000 in its top spec, it’s not a huge percentage. 

Nevertheless, it’s good to see Specialized’s prices for its bikes heading in the right direction after a period of substantial price inflation; when we reviewed the S-Works Tarmac SL7 in October 2020, its list price was £10,500, while as of August 2023 it’s currently listed at £13,000 on Specialized’s site. 

That price decrease has trickled down the range as well, making the Tarmac SL8 a slightly more affordable proposition than the Tarmac SL7, although it’s not currently offered in the lowest price Comp and Sport specs.

Specialized Tarmac SL8 vs. Tarmac SL7 models

The Tarmac SL8 will be available initially at just three spec levels: S-Works, Pro and Expert, with two groupset options each at S-Works and Pro levels. 

If you want the top spec bike, the flagship £12,000 S-Works Tarmac SL8 Dura-Ace Di2 is equipped with a 52/36 / 11-30 Dura-Ace groupset with a 4iiii Precision Pro dual-sided power meter and Roval Rapide CLX II tubeless-ready wheelset. Claimed weight for a size 56cm is 6.62kg.

The cheapest option is the Tarmac SL8 Expert, priced at £6,000. This is specced with a SRAM Rival AXS 48/35 single sided power meter crankset with 10-36 cassette and Roval C38 carbon wheels. Claimed weight for a size 56cm is 7.77kg.

In contrast, the SL7 is currently available at S-Works, Expert and Comp levels, with two groupset options for each level. 

The Tarmac SL7 Comp with Shimano 105 Di2 is available from Specialized in sizes 52cm and over and in three colours for £5,000. 

Specialized also has the Tarmac SL7 Expert available to buy for £7,250 in two colours and sizes from 49cm.

There are more limited size/colour options at Specialized too for the £13,000 S-Works Tarmac SL7 Shimano Dura-Ace Di2.

Specialized will in future offer the Tarmac SL7 at Comp and Sport levels. This continues its practice of offering older models at lower specs; the Tarmac SL6 is currently still available from Specialized at Sport level in a limited range of sizes.
